RNA&cancer&category: RNA cancer category is based on analysis of RNA-seq data from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA).||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#rna
RNA&CS&TPM: RNA CS TPM indicates RNA level (TPM) in cell lines with elevated RNA expression.||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#rna
Reliability&(IH): Reliability score, divided into Enhanced, Supported, Approved, or Uncertain, is evaluated in normal tissues and based on consistency between antibody staining pattern, available RNA-Seq and gene/protein characterization data, as well as similarity between independent antibodies targeting the same protein.||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#ihre
TPM&max&in&non-specific: Highest RNA level, reported as mean TPM (transcripts per million), among tissues that do not have elevated RNA expression.
RNA&TS: RNA TS indicates tissue specificity (TS) score for tissues with elevated RNA expression, calculated as fold change to the next highest tissue.||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#rna
Reliability&(Mouse&Brain): Reliability score, divided into Supported or Uncertain, is set for all genes and indicates the level of reliability of the analyzed protein expression pattern based on available protein/RNA/gene characterization data.||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#ifmre
Protein&class: Protein class the gene product belongs to according to selected gene lists.||||List of protein classes : https://www.proteinatlas.org/humanproteome/proteinclasses
RNA&tissue&category: RNA category is based on mRNA expression levels in the analyzed tissue samples (RNA assay description).||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#rna
Prognostic&link: The url of Prognostic information of this gene.
Prognostic&p-value: P-value of Kaplan-Meier analysis for all cancers where high expression of the gene is associated with favorable prognosis (green) or unfavorable prognosis (red) with regard to patient survival.||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#tcga_survival
Gene&synonym: Synonyms according to Ensembl and Entrez.
Ensembl: Gene identification number according to Ensembl.
Antibody: Antibodies used for immunohistochemistry (results presented in Tissue and Pathology Atlas) and immunocytochemistry/IF (results presented in Cell Atlas)assays. ||||The assays are described in detail in:||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#ih
RNA&CS: RNA CS indicates cell specificity (CS) score for cell lines with elevated RNA expression, calculated as fold change to the next highest cell line.||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#rna
Evidence: generated from several independent sources and are classified as evidence at:||||i) protein level, ||||ii) transcript level, ||||iii) no evidence, ||||iv) not available.
RNA&cell&line&category: RNA category is based on mRNA expression levels in the analyzed tissue samples (RNA assay description).
Reliability&(IF): Reliability score, divided into Enhanced, Supported, Approved, or Uncertain, is evaluated in cell lines and based on consistency between antibody staining pattern, available RNA-Seq and gene/protein characterization data, as well as similarity between independent antibodies targeting the same protein.||||https://www.proteinatlas.org/about/assays+annotation#ifre
RNA&TS&TPM: RNA TS TPM indicates RNA level reported as mean TPM (transcripts per million), in tissues with elevated RNA expression.
_db_description: The Human Protein Atlas is a Swedish-based program initiated in 2003 with the aim to map all the human proteins in cells, tissues and organs using integration of various omics technologies, including antibody-based imaging, mass spectrometry-based proteomics, transcriptomics and systems biology.||||1)the Tissue Atlas ||||showing the distribution of the proteins across all major tissues and organs in the human body.||||2)the Cell Atlas ||||showing the subcellular localization of proteins in single cells.||||3)the Pathology Atlas ||||showing the impact of protein levels for survival of patients with cancer.
